ContentClassification.TableReference: Central Statistics Office, “Saorstat Life Table No. 1”, Central Statistics Office (Ireland, 1926) Accessed: July, 2014 from http://www.cso.ie/en/media/csoie/census/census1926results/volume5/C,1926,VOL,5-1,memorandum.pdf and http://www.cso.ie/en/media/csoie/census/census1926results/volume5/C,1926,VOL,5-1,T22.pdf
ContentClassification.TableName: Saorstát Éireann Life Table No. 1 (1925-27) Males
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Saorstát Éireann (The Irish Free State) Life Table No. 1 (1925-27) Males. Minimum Age: 0 Maximum Age: 107
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: For ages 5 years and over, table calculated from the population in 1926 as recorded at the Census and the number of deaths in 1925, 1926, and 1927 as recorded in the annual returns of the Registrar-General of Saorstát Éireann (The Irish Free State). Methodology: Central death rates calculated at pivotal ages of x. Graduation of the central values employed Mr. King’s method with modification as there was a very marked tendency towards giving ages in round numbers such as 40, 50, 60, etc. Values for ages 33 to 39 were calculated by a Lagrangean interpolation while other intervening values calculated by osculatory interpolation. At ages 0 to 4, the values of qx were based solely on vital statistics using Sir Alfred Watson’s formula. The remaining values of qx from x=5 to x=16 were calculated by a Lagranean interpolation formula. Neither Mr. King’s fourth difference formula nor Sir Alfred Watson’s Gompertz graduation was sufficiently accurate hence a Makeham graduation was used for the qx of advanced ages. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 07/2014

MetaData.TableDescription: Saorstát Éireann (The Irish Free State) Life Table No. 1 (1925-27) Males. Minimum Age: 0 Maximum Age: 107
